qas.question: What unit was used in the DIN to express speeds?
How was sensitivity expressed at first in the DIN system?

answers.text: as a fraction with 'tenths' (for example "18/10° DIN")

qas.question: When did the degree symbol fall out of use in the DIN system?
Why did the definition of film speeds change considerably?

answers.text: to accommodate then-recent changes in the American ASA PH2.5-1960 standard

qas.question: What happened to film speeds of black-and-white negative film?
What replaced the American ASA PH2.5-1960 standard?
What system reintroduced the degree symbol?
What American standard abandoned the tenths method?
With emulsion changes, what did 18° DIN become?
What happened to film speeds after the introduction of the DIN 4512:1957-11?

context: As in the Scheiner system, speeds were expressed in '<a0_0>degrees<a0_0/>'. Originally the sensitivity was written <a1_0>as a fraction with 'tenths' (for example "18/10° DIN")<a1_0/>, where the resultant value 1.8 represented the relative base 10 logarithm of the speed. 'Tenths' were later abandoned with <b7_0>DIN 4512:1957-11<b7_0/>, and the example above would be written as "18° DIN". The degree symbol was finally dropped <a2_0>with <b5_0>DIN 4512:1961-10<b5_0/><a2_0/>. This revision also saw significant changes in the definition of film speeds in order <a3_0>to accommodate then-recent changes in the American <b6_0>ASA PH2.5-1960<b6_0/> standard<a3_0/>, so that film speeds of black-and-white negative film effectively <a4_0><b9_0>would become doubled<b9_0/><a4_0/>, that is, a film previously marked as "18° DIN" would now be labeled as "<b8_0>21 DIN<b8_0/>" without emulsion changes.
